STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 25, 2022
Linda Needham
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
RE: License #: CP580201306
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
03/11/2022. An exit Conference was held with you on 03/21/2022. Due to the violations,
a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any
licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP580201306
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Linda Needham, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Monroe County DHHS
Facility Address: 903 S Telegraph Road
Monroe, MI 48161
Facility Telephone #: (734) 243-7203
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1989
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):03/07/2022 thru 03/11/2022

Reviewed

Independent Living Youth

Adoptive Parents
Others (please identify person interviewed by role)
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of three new employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s six month’s performance evaluation due by
2/9/2022 was completed late on 2/26/2022.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to
the department, when requested, the facts the department
requires with reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection
and subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the childcare organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information.
One of four special evaluations reviewed showed CPS was
involved in the investigation and indicated CPS language.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
4

Two of four closed foster home records reviewed showed the
agency’s recommendation to the department occurred two and
four days prior to the respective foster home’s 12/4/2021 and
12/7/2021 expiration date. The respective foster home had
requested voluntary closure on 10/26/2021 and 11/15/2021.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
Four of four special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Four did not show consistent or clear documentation of
the interviewer, where all interviews occurred and or
those interviewed, as required by (d).
 Three did not show a clear analysis/summary of findings
of facts based on the evaluation, as required by(e).
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
One of four special evaluations reviewed showed the foster
parent was not provided a copy of the report with 10 days of the
special evaluation’s 2/4/2022 completion. It was provided on
2/24/2022.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (e) as required by the rule.
5

Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim May 2021.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
Two of six open child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of the child’s
dental due by 9/7/2021.
 A second record showed the child’s dental due by
10/30/2021 was completed 20 days late on 11/19/2021.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 20 updated service plans (USP) reviewed was four days
late.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show documentation that the youth was provided a copy of the
program statement.
Repeat Violation- Interim May 2021.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
6

One of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show documentation that the youth was provided a copy of the
agency’s policies and procedures.
Repeat Violation- Interim May 2021.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
One of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show documentation of an assessment showing the
appropriateness of the independent living placement for the
youth.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's housing,
clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is available.
One of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show documentation of (f) as required by the rule for initial
placement.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show documentation of mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and agency.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three open independent living records reviewed did not
show compliance:
7

 One record did not show documentation of a quarterly
contract due in November 2021.
 A second record showed the youth’s contract due in April
2021(per the last one dated 1/12/2021) was completed
late on 6/8/2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim May 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MSA requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
Four of 24 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 Two did not show documentation of the birth parent’s
signature on the child’s 3/11/2021-5/27/2021 and
8/10/2021-11/2/2021 treatment plan.
 Two others did not show documentation of the respective
youth’s signature on a 7/1/2021-9/28/2021 and
10/30/2021-1/24/2022 treatment plan.
Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim 2021, cited
under R400.12403(2)(i) Policy and procedures.
3) Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except for the
following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
8

community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Four of six open foster child records; and one of three open
independent living records reviewed did not show compliance
as required by the policy:
 One child’s record did not show an FTM for the child’s
8/31/2021-11/28/2021 USP.
 A second child’s record did not show an FTM for the
child’s 5/28/2021-8/9/2021; 8/10/2021-11/2/2021 or
11/2/2021-1/20/2022 USP. One was completed sooner
than required on 6/30/2021 for the first listed USP and
after the period on 1/24/2022 for the last listed USP.
 A third child’s record did not show an FTM for the child’s
11/25/2021-2/11/2022 USP. Nor a DHS-1105 for a
documented 12/24/2021 FTM.
 A fourth child’s record did not show an FTM for the child’s
6/19/2021-9/13/2021 USP. Nor a DHS-1105 for a
documented 11/22/2021 USP.
 The independent living youth record did not show an
FTM for the youth’s 9/29/2021-12/7/2021 USP. One was
completed after the period on 12/8/2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim May 2021.
FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of 24 services plans was approved five days late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim 2021, cited
under R400.12403(2)(i) Policy and procedures.
FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
9

MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
 Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure.
 Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
Three of five closed child records, and one of one closed
independent living youth records, reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Two records did not show a DHS-69 for the respective
child’s 1/28/2021 and 3/1/2021 return to a birth parent.
 The third child’s record showed the child’s DHS-69 for a
9/11/2021 case closure was completed late on
10/11/2021.
 The independent living youth record did not show a DHS-
69 for the youth’s 9/13/2021 program case closure.
801-03 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and Quarterly.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation that the medical passport was
completed quarterly and provided to the caregiver or birth
parent.
Repeat Violation- Renewal March 2020; Interim 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12420(1)(g) Updated service plans.
10

 The agency was advised it shall consistently document the specific
behavioral management plan to be used by the foster parent/caregiver for
a child of all ages.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s May 2021 Interim Inspection where
it received the following citations:
 R400.12209(1) Orientation and training.
 R400.1212(3)(b) Personnel records.
 R400.12326(1)(g) Borrowed home.
 R400.12326(1)(b) Special evaluation.
 R400.12403(2) Policy and procedures.
 R400.12405(3)(a)-(j) Change of placement.
 R400.12418(2)(a) Development of service plans.
 R400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
 R400.12422(3)(e) Foster care record.
 R400.12502 Program statement.
 R400.12503 Policies and procedures.
 R400.12504(2)(a) Supervision.
 R400.12509(3) Independent living record.
 R400.12510(2) Independent living contract.
 FOM 722-03C Older Youth; Preparation, placement, and discharge.
 FOM 722-06B- Family team meeting.
 FOM 722-06H Caseworker contact with children in out of home placement.
 FOM 722-06 H Timely entry of caseworker contacts.
 FOM 722-07 F Annual review/change form.
The agency made some gains in various areas of their corrective action plan but were
not totally successful with completion of all. The agency received repeat violations, as
indicated in this report.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts this inspection.
11

VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date March 23, 2022
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 25, 2022
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
12
